content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks fun to code ;)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice concept! I think this would really work in shortest mode as well. Nicely done.
I have a question: have you considered having more than two spaces in a row (and "j" would jump to the next available tile)? Or do you think it would get too hard for a Coc?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fine, it's good and clear.

I liked the idea and it's very simple and I accept it for Fastest and Shortest modes. I just faced two issues during the analysis.
1. After testing, I saw that your first input was wrong, I think that it may be 5 not 8 the length of the bridge.
2. I think that it would be better to present the expected output during the presention of the statment to make the one who is doing it more used to it mainly if it's in the fastest mode.

1. Yes it's 5, fixed!
2. I'm trying to keep it short, and follow the blocks suggested by codingame.

Thanks for the review!
Yes I thought about it, but how it is now is already a little hard for a CoC (5mins maximum)

I think we can still read that there may be "two holes in a row".

So, in the Statement and/or Constraints, we should mention that there are no two holes in a row. (Note: With this, it will not be required to emphasize "one space".)

I think, there is nothing such as two holes in a row. That goes against the definition of a hole: generally a hole is defined by depth, length, position.

So two empty spaces would be called one big hole, but not two adjacent holes.

Your argument makes sense. Possibly, I viewed from different angle, so I will write what I thought as a note.

In my image of daily life, the hole is typically round and near to circle, and not a square. It is similar to puddles in the rain.

So, what I imagined as "picture" of this problem is many circular holes in the bridge. In real world, two holes may be so near and they may be jumped over at the same time.
